S2095-4956(25)00118-4 10.1016/j.jechem.2025.01.055 Science Press Fig. 1 SEM images of (a) NF, (b) Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, and (c) Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. (d) TEM image of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF; (e) HRTEM image of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and (f, g) the corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT) patterns of the selected representative crystalline domains marked in (e). (h) The SAED pattern of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF; (i–l) Mappings of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. Fig. 2 (a) X-ray diffraction patterns of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and a bare NF. (b) Raman spectra of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. (c) Electron paramagnetic resonance spectra of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. High-resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy spectra of the (d) Ni 2p region, (e) Fe 2p region, and (f) S 2p regions of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. Fig. 3 The initial 50-cycle CV curves of (a) Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF and (b) Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1 in 1 M KOH. Fig. 4 OER properties of different electrocatalysts in 1 M KOH solution: (a) LSV curve, (b) LSV curve at high current density, (c) Tafel slope, (d) corresponding overpotential at 500 mA cm−2 and corresponding Tafel slope, (e) C dl, and (f) OER current density diagram using C dl as the standard. (g) Chronopotentiometry curves of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF at a current density of 500 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH. Fig. 5 (a–c) Polarization curves of the Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF and Ni2Fe1S2/NF in 1.0 M KOH and 1.0 M TMAOH. (d–g) Plots of log j vs. log [OH−] for the Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF and Vs-Ni3S2/NF. (h) Plots of Ni3+/2+ reduction peak potential with pH. (i) The Arrhenius plots. Fig. 6 Bode phase curves under the different potentials of the (a) Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, (b) Vs-Ni3S2/NF, (c) Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and (d) Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. (e) The phase angle of various electrocatalysts at specific applied potentials. (f) Bode phase curves of different electrocatalysts at 1.51 VRHE. (g) Nyquist plots at 1.51 VRHE. (h) Constant phase angle element (CPE) values of different electrodes relative to the applied potential. (i) Different electrodes correspond to the total resistance (R total) of different applied potentials. Fig. 7 (a) D-band centers of Ni3S2, Ni2Fe1S2, and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2. (b) The molecular structure corresponding to (a). (c) The differential charge density of Ni3S2, Ni2Fe1S2, and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2. (d, e) Gibbs free energy diagrams of the OER at 0 and 1.23 V. (f) Total density of states diagram. (g–i) Projected density of states diagrams. Fig. 8 (a) 10 mA cm−2 galvanostatic test of the Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF in 1 M KOH. (b) LSV and (c) Nyquist plots of the Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF before and after the 100h galvanostatic test. (d) The 2.5 mA cm−2 galvanostatic test for the Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF in 1 M KOH. (e) XRD pattern and (f) Raman spectra of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF after the galvanostatic OER test. Deconvoluted high-resolution XPS spectra of the (g) Ni 2p, (h) Fe 2p, and (i) S 2p regions, and region of the Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF after the long-term galvanostatic OER test. Fig. 9 HER and overall water splitting performance of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF in 1 M KOH. (a) Polarization curve, (b) Tafel slope diagram, (c) corresponding overpotential and Tafel slope. (d) Polarization curve in 1 M KOH. (e) Long-term galvanostatic test at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH. (f) Polarization curve in 30 wt% KOH and 70 °. (g) Stability test at 100 mA cm−2 in 30 wt% KOH. (h) Comparison of properties of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF with reported superior catalysts in 1 M and 30 wt% KOH. Scheme 1 Schematic illustration for the preparation of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. Graphical abstract S-vacancies and iron-doped nickel sulfide nanosheets exhibit high electrocatalytic performance and durability for oxygen evolution. The development of high-performance and stable electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is essential to improve the overall efficiency of water splitting. Here, S-vacancies and iron-doped nickel sulfide nanosheets (Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF) were successfully prepared on the surface of nickel foam via solvothermal reaction of nickel–iron layered double hydroxide with sublimed sulfur added with sodium borohydride. Under the synergistic regulation of iron-doped and S-vacancies, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF shows excellent electrocatalytic performance and long-term durability. To reach current densities of 10 and 500 mA cm−2, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF requires only 185 (±5) and 248 (±5) mV overpotential, respectively, and can maintain long stability for 350 h at 500 mA cm−2. The change of the mechanical pathway from adsorbate evolution mechanism to lattice oxygen oxidation mechanism is due to the increased acidity of the Ni site in Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, which facilitates the decouped proton and electron transfer process. Density functional calculation results show that the introduction of Fe atoms and S vacancies in Ni3S2 can enhance the conductivity of the intermediates by regulating the electronic structure of the intermediates, optimize the adsorption or desorption energy, and thus significantly improve the OER activity. For Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF (+, −) cell, a voltage of 1.56 V is required to achieve 10 mA cm−2. In addition, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF catalyst also showed low overpotential (270 mV at 100 mA cm−2) and high alkaline tolerance (100 h at 100 mA cm−2) at 30 wt% KOH of 70 °C. This shows that it has potential industrial application. Keywords NiFe-layered double hydroxide Iron-doped nickel sulfide S-vacancies Oxygen evolution Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) plays a crucial role in energy conversion devices [1,2], including aqueous metal-air batteries and water electrolyzers [3]. Besides, OER is the anode reaction for cathode electrochemical refining, such as CO2 reduction [4], nitrogen reduction [5], hydrogen evolution [6], hydrogen peroxide generation [7], hydrogenation reaction [8], etc. However, due to the slow kinetics of the four-electron transfer reaction involving O-H fracture and O-O formation, the energy conversion efficiency is limited [9]. Industrial water electrolysis electrocatalysts should have several notable characteristics, including high intrinsic activity, large specific surface area to expose active sites, good electrical conductivity, high durability, and good stability at high current densities (>500 mA cm−2), high temperatures (60–80 °C), and high alkali concentrations (20–30 wt% KOH) [10]. Unfortunately, there are few electrocatalytic materials that can meet this demanding condition, and most of the research focuses on microscopic and intrinsic properties of the electrocatalysts, and the conditions that are close to practical uses are lacking in the evaluation of electrocatalytic properties. Therefore, the development of efficient electrocatalysts that can be applied in the practical OER operational states is important. In general, precious metal-based catalysts such as IrO2 and RuO2 exhibit excellent OER activities. However, the stability of precious metal-based catalysts at high potentials is poor. Transition metal-based catalysts have the potential for large-scale application owing to their advantages of cost-effectiveness, abundant resources, and adjustable electronic structure. In particular, transition metal electrocatalysts with 3D orbitals exhibit comparable OER performance with precious metal catalysts. Nickel oxides or hydroxides exhibit excellent OER catalytic activity in alkaline environment. Studies have shown that NiFe layered double hydroxide (NiFe-LDH) is considered to be a highly active and stable alkaline OER electrocatalyst, and its catalytic activity even exceeds that of IrO2 [10]. Fe is low-cost, non-toxic, and highly abundant in the Earth's crust. However, the low conductivity of NiFe-LDH limits its catalytic activity. In order to improve the conductivity and to avoid the use of conductive polymer binders, the electrocatalysts are generally grown directly on the conductive substrate (usually nickel foam as in commercial water electrolyzers) [11]. Transition metal phosphides [12], selenides [13], sulfides [14], and hydroxides [15] also exhibit high electrocatalytic activities towards OER. Among them, transition metal sulfides, particularly nickel-based sulfides, have drawn considerable attention due to their distinctive d-electron structure, low cost, and good conductivity [16]. Nickel-based sulfides are constructed with various synthetic strategies to reduce overpotential and promote the OER. For example, the introduction of heteroatoms into a Ni-based sulfide catalyst can regulate its electronic structure, thereby improving the intrinsic properties of the catalyst. Huang et al. prepared Fe-doped NiS-NiS2 heterogeneous microspheres, and it is verified by density functional theory (DFT) simulation that Fe-doped improves the conductivity of nickel sulfides, resulting in low overpotential and high electrocatalytic activity [17]. Chen et al. successfully prepared Se-doped NiS2 and showed excellent OER activity and stability under alkaline conditions, requiring an overpotential of 343 mV at a current density of 50 mA cm−2 [18]. Vacancy engineering strategies are also widely used to increase catalytic activity by exposing more active sites on the catalyst surface. Xue et al. controlled the amount of oxygen vacancy of CoO by adjusting the content of Mn doping, which was positively correlated with the catalytic performance. The catalytic activity of OER was extremely high 301 and 322 mV at 50 mA cm−2 under alkaline and acidic conditions, respectively [19]. Therefore, using heteroatom doping and vacancy engineering to co-regulate the surface activity of catalysts could be an effective strategy for constructing excellent OER catalysts. In catalytic processes, dopant atoms can modulate the electron density of the catalyst and/or serve as active sites. Similarly, vacancies not only influence the electron density but also enhance the exposure of additional active sites, thereby improving the catalytic performance. Employing these two strategies to design catalytic materials and investigating their synergistic effects on catalytic activity are crucial for developing efficient catalysts. Transition metal chalcogenides have also been identified as promising pre-catalysts, demonstrating excellent electrochemical properties and high electrical conductivity [20]. Upon oxidation of surface-bound sulfides or other compounds on the pre-catalyst, they can transform into the corresponding oxides and (oxy)hydroxides. These reconstructed species have been identified as the true active sites responsible for catalysis [21]. Significantly, the reconstructed surface demonstrates superior OER activity compared to metal oxides and (oxy)hydroxides synthesized directly [22]. In this work, S-vacancies and iron-doped nickel sulfide nanosheets (Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF) were prepared on the surface of nickel foam. S-vacancies and iron-doped engineering were successfully combined by hydrothermal and solvothermal methods as effective OER catalysts for alkaline water splitting. First, the Ni2Fe1-LDH precursor (Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF) is grown on NF by hydrothermal synthesis. Sodium borohydride (NaBH4) was then mixed with sublimed sulfur powder in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) using a one-step solvothermal process to successfully vulcanize and introduce S-vacancies into iron-doped nickel disulfide (Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF). The introduction of anionic vacancies effectively alters the electronic structure near the reaction site, facilitating the adsorption of catalytic intermediates and thereby enhancing OER activity. As expected, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF exhibits excellent electrocatalytic properties and excellent durability for both OER (overpotential at 500 mA·cm−2 (η 500), 248 mV) and overall water splitting (OWS) (10 mA·cm−2 with a cell of only 1.56 V). In addition, the potential of its industrial application is studied under the condition of industrial water electrolysis. The results show that Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF has great application prospect in large-scale industrial water electrolysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF All chemicals are analytically pure and are listed in the supporting information. The treatment of NF is described in the supporting information. Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (2 mmol), FeSO4·7H2O (1 mmol), NH4F (10 mmol) and urea (25 mmol) were mixed in 30 mL of water. The resulting solution was poured into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave with a piece of 3 × 2 cm2 cleaned NF. The hydrothermal process was carried out at 120 °C in an electric oven for 6 h. After natural cooling to room temperature, the Ni2Fe1-LDH coated on NF was washed with deionized water, and then blown dry under a stream of compressed air. The mass of Ni2Fe1-LDH on NF is weighed by a laboratory balance to 5 mg cm−2. 2.2 Preparation of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF 100 mg of sulfur sublimed powder and 200 mg of NaBH4 were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF. Then, they were poured into a 50 mL Teflon autoclave. The prepared Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF was leaned against the wall of a Teflon autoclave for a 1.5 h solvothermal reaction at 180°C. After natural cooling, the Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF was removed from the autoclave, washed with ethanol and water, and vacuum dried at 60 °C for 6 h. The electrodes were cropped to 1 × 2 cm2 for testing. The mass of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF was measured by a laboratory balance of 2.0 mg cm−2. The preparation processes of Vs-Ni3S2/NF and Ni2Fe1S2/NF are described in the supporting information. 3 Results and discussion The preparation method for Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF is depicted in Scheme 1 . Firstly, Ni2Fe1-LDH precursor was prepared on NF by hydrothermal method. Then NaBH4 was mixed with sublimed sulfur in DMF, and the solvothermal reaction at 180 °C for 1.5 h converted Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF to Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. The formation of S vacancies is attributed to the etching caused by the strong reducibility of NaBH4 [12]. During the synthesis process, the color of the sample changes from yellow to black (Fig. S1). Fe3+ enters the crystalline nickel sulfide structure as a dopant. This self-growth strategy establishes an electron transport pathway between the substrate and the catalyst, thereby ensuring the catalyst's high conductivity. Furthermore, the robust chemical bonding between the catalyst layer and the substrate provides enhanced electrode stability under industrial current densities [23]. The morphologies of the samples were analyzed by SEM. The original NF presents a porous network structure with a smooth surface (Fig. 1 a). After hydrothermal treatment, Ni2Fe1-LDH precursors with a two-dimensional nanosheet structure were observed to grow on the NF surface (Fig. 1b). The Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF precursor comprises polygonal sheets, ranging from 3 to 5 µm in lateral dimension, with smooth surfaces and a thickness of 40–100 nm. Interestingly, many Ni2Fe1-LDH nanosheets spontaneously assemble, forming flower-like forms at certain edges of NF. After reaction with sulfur powder and sodium borohydride under solvothermal conditions, Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF is transformed into Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF (Fig. 1c). Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF inherits the floral morphology of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF. It is worth noting that almost all of the nanoflowers collapsed to varying degrees after sulfidation, possibly because the fulcrum between the nanosheets was etched. In addition, as shown in Figs. S22 and S23, Ni2Fe1S2/NF has completely different morphologies compared with Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. Due to the etching of NaBH4, many irregular pits were formed on the surface of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF nanosheets. These interwoven pits increase the specific surface area, allowing the full exposure of active sites and providing convenient channels for proton transport. This enhances the contact between the reactants and the catalyst surface, thereby improving its catalytic performance. The microstructure and morphology of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF were further analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM). The image in Fig. 1d shows that the Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF sheets are disordered interlacing or overlapping horizontally, and many small irregular rings are visible in TEM, which is consistent with the surface pits observed in SEM. The HRTEM image (Fig. 1e) and the fast Fourier transform (FFT) image (Fig. 1f and g) of the selected region of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF have lattice fringes with the spacing of 0.287 and 0.237 nm, corresponding to the (110) and (003) planes of the Ni3S2 phase, respectively. In addition, Fig. S26d shows defects in the lattice, where the missing “points of light” may be atomic vacancies [24]. The SAED diffraction pattern also confirms the presence of Ni3S2 crystals in Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF (Fig. 1h). High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) images and corresponding energy dispersion spectrum (EDS) element mapping images (Fig. 1i–l; Fig. S21) confirm the uniform distribution of Ni, Fe and S elements in the catalyst. This further confirms the successful formation of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. In addition, the crystal structure and chemical state of the samples were further analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. 2 a, all samples show three strong diffraction peaks of NF substrate at 44.5°, 51.9°, and 76.4° (JCPDS 04-0850) [25]. For Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, diffraction peaks are observed at 11.55°, 23.13°, 34.50°, 39.03°, 46.24°, 59.95°, and 61.27°, which correspond to the (003), (006), (012), (015), (018), (110), and (113) planes of the NiFe-LDH phase (JCPDS 040-0215) [26]. After sulfidation, the characteristic peaks of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF at 22.0°, 31.1°, 37.7°, 38.2°, 49.8°, 50.1°, 55.1° also match well with Ni3S2 (JCPDS 44-1418) standard cards, which further proved that Ni3S2 material was successfully synthesized on NF [27]. At the same time, the XRD pattern of Ni2Fe1S2/NF is shown in Fig. S4. It can be seen that the main phase of Ni2Fe1S2/NF is Ni3S2 (JCPDS 44-1418), and the main phase of Ni2Fe1S2/NF is the same as that of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. This shows that the addition of sodium borohydride does not change the crystalline phase. Fig. 2b shows the Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF Raman spectra. Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF shows Raman displacements at 292, 452, and 532 cm−1, corresponding to E-type, M−O(H), and M−O modes, respectively [28]. Peaks at 217 and 291 cm−1 are attributed to the Ni–S bond and correspond to the vibration peaks of Ni3S2 [29,30]. To further confirm the specific vacancy type of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, Fig. 2c shows the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrum of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, where the strong signal at g = 2.003 comes from the anionic S vacancies [10]. These results indicate that Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF forms high S vacancies due to the sulfidation process, which is consistent with the HRTEM results observed in Fig. S26. To investigate the effects of Fe, Ni, and S elements and further confirm the formation of vacancies, XPS was employed to analyze the surface elemental composition and oxidation states. Fig. 2d–f show the high-resolution XPS spectra of the Ni 2p, Fe 2p, and S 2p orbits of the corresponding samples, respectively. The spectra of all samples were calibrated by a C 1s peak located at 284.8 eV. Fig. S2 shows the complete XPS spectra of the different samples, where only the Ni, Fe, S, F, C, and O elements are observed. For the Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, as shown in Fig. 2d, the Ni 2p spectrum displays two distinct peaks at 854.9 and 872.7 eV, along with two satellite peaks at 860.2 and 878.1 eV, confirming the presence of Ni2+ [31,32]. In the Fe 2p spectrum (Fig. 2e), discernible peaks corresponding to Fe3+ were observed at energy levels of 712.5 and 725.6 eV for Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2, respectively [33]. The peaks of Fe and Ni in Ni2Fe1S2/NF and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF move in the direction of lower binding energies compared to Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, suggesting the electronic interaction between the metal and sulfur atoms [34]. For the Ni2Fe1S2/NF spectrum, the peaks are 856 eV (Ni2+, 2p 3/2), 874 eV (Ni2+, 2p 1/2), 861.6 eV (sat.) and 879.9 eV (sat.). The 852.8 eV peak at Ni2Fe1S2/NF is not present in Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, which can be attributed to the metallic nickel in nickel sulfide [35]. Compared with Ni2Fe1S2/NF, the peaks of Ni 2p 3/2 (855.5 eV) and Ni 2p 1/2 (873.3 eV) XPS attributed to the Ni–S bond in Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF have a negative shift of about 0.5 and 0.7 eV, respectively. This means that the electron density of Ni in Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF increases and the chemical valence number of Ni decreases. The lower chemical valence number of Ni in Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF is due to sulfur vacancies [36]. In the Fe 2p region, two distinct peaks are observed at 724 eV (Fe3+, 2p 1/2) and 711.2 eV (Fe3+, 2p 3/2), indicating the presence of Fe in the form of Fe3+ dopant in Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, with no formation of iron sulfide phase. For Ni2Fe1S2/NF, in the S 2p spectrum, a peak appears at 168.5 eV, corresponding to the characteristic peak of SO4 2−, which may be caused by the inevitable oxidation of the surface of Ni2Fe1S2/NF in air [37]. The peaks at 162.1, 163.5 and 164.9 eV correspond to the characteristic peaks of S 2p 3/2, S 2p 1/2 and Ni–S bond of Ni2Fe1S2/NF catalyst S2−, respectively. However, for Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, the characteristic peaks of S2− 2p 3/2 and S2− 2p 1/2 become stronger and move to lower binding energies of 160.6 and 162.1 eV compared to Ni2Fe1S2/NF. The results show that S vacancies are successfully introduced into Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF [10]. To activate the catalyst and explore the surface reconstruction of the catalyst, cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests were performed in a standard three-electrode system with a voltage range of 1.061 to 1.661 V and a scanning rate of 50 mV s−1 without iR compensation (Fig. 3 a, b). Both Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF exhibit dynamic self-restructuring during CV cycling, which is due to the generation of new active species. For Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, two cathode peaks appear at about 1.24 and 1.34 VRHE, respectively. This can be attributed to the reduction of γ-(NiFe)OOH and β-(NiFe)OOH → Ni x Fe y (OH)2 [38]. For Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, only one significant reduction peak was observed on the CV. The anode peak is not distinctly observed, likely due to the overlap between the oxidation peak and the OER current [39]. The current density initially decreases before increasing, suggesting that surface reconstruction enhances the OER process. The current of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF is initially higher than 0, primarily resulting from the oxidative leaching of anions during the first cycle [40]. For Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, the reduction peak shift is much smaller than that for Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF under the same conditions. These results suggest that in Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, Ni2+ can generate active species (Ni3+) at a lower potential. The OER properties of these electrodes were first evaluated in 1 M KOH. Halogen may affect the morphology and activity of electrocatalysts [41]. The OER activity of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF synthesized with and without NH4F was investigated. The corresponding LSV curves confirmed that there is little difference in OER activity between Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF synthesized with and without NH4F at high current density. (Fig. S5). Subsequently, the influence of the Ni-Fe ratio on reactivity was explored and the optimal Ni-Fe ratio was found (Fig. S6). The electrochemical properties of all samples are summarized in Table 1 . Cathodic LSV (Fig. 4 a) was used to assess OER activity to avoid the influence of Ni2+/Ni3+ oxidation peaks. The measured LSV curves show that bare NF has poor OER activity, while Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF and Vs-Ni3S2/NF have moderate OER activity. In contrast, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF exhibits excellent OER activity at 10 mA cm−2 with overpotential as low as 185 mV. Furthermore, Fig. 4b presents the LSV curves of various catalysts at elevated current densities. Notably, 500 and 1000 mA cm−2 are typically employed in industrial settings. The Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF demonstrates exceptionally low overpotentials of only 248 and 270 mV, respectively. This means that it has potential for industrial applications. The Tafel slope (Fig. 4c), a key indicator of reaction kinetics, was further investigated. Among the catalysts tested, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF exhibits the lowest Tafel slope of 24.18 mV dec−1, signifying the most rapid reaction kinetics. In contrast, Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and Vs-Ni3S2/NF show Tafel slopes of 61.28, 102.81, and 140.39 mV dec−1, respectively (Fig. 4d). To gain deeper insight into the intrinsic catalytic activity of the catalyst, the turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated, as summarized in Fig. S19. The TOF of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF at 1.53 V is 0.18 mol O2 s−1, significantly surpassing that of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF (0.08 mol O2 s−1), Ni2Fe1S2/NF (0.05 mol O2 s−1) and Vs-Ni3S2/NF (0.0032 mol O2 s−1). These results highlight the superior intrinsic catalytic activity of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. In order to further explore the different electrochemical activities of various catalysts, by measuring CV (Fig. S7) of the non-Faraday region at different scanning rates (v) and plotting the relationship between I and v, double-layer capacitance (C dl) proportional to the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) can be obtained, as shown in Fig. 4e. The C dl value of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF is 8.69 mF⋅cm−2, which is significantly higher than that of Ni2Fe1S2/NF (4.92 mF⋅cm−2) and Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF (2.34 mF⋅cm−2). Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF has higher ECSA and more active sites available. The C dl of Vs-Ni3S2/NF is higher than that of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, but the OER activity is poor and the Tafel slope is lower than that of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, indicating that doping Fe3+ could not improve ECSA. But this does not necessarily mean that catalytic activity is reduced. The incorporation of Fe may induce structural changes on the Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF surface, leading to the creation of new catalytic active sites [42]. By normalizing the current density to C dl (Fig. 4f), Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF shows the highest I/C dl, which indicates the highest OER activity of unit ECSA. Thus, the observed high OER activity of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF is attributed to the enhanced intrinsic activity of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. In addition, galvanostatic tests show that Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF has excellent stability at 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. S13) and 500 mA cm−2 (Fig. 4g). The potential line fluctuates due to the diurnal temperature. At the same time, due to the consumption and evaporation of electrolytes required for hydrogen and oxygen generation during long-term OER testing, electrolyte replenishment is essential. This further demonstrates that Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF can be used for industrial applications. The mechanism path of OER is different. Compared with traditional adsorbent evolution mechanism (AEM), lattice oxygen oxidation mechanism (LOM) realizes the O–O coupling of oxygen by participating in OER reaction through lattice oxygen, avoiding the adsorption limitation of *OOH, and makes the catalyst show good catalytic performance [43]. Since the LOM pathway involves the formation of oxidized oxygen states, the identification of oxidized oxygen intermediates can provide strong evidence to confirm the mechanism of LOM. Tetraalkylammonium cation (TMA+) can be used as a chemical probe to identify oxidized oxygen intermediates. The specific binding of TMA+ to negatively charged oxygen molecules blocks the LOM pathway [44]. As shown in Fig. 5 a–c, the OER activity of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and Ni2Fe1S2/NF decreases significantly in 1.0 M TMAOH electrolyte compared with 1.0 M KOH electrolyte. This implies binding between TMA+ and O2 2− and verifies that Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and Ni2Fe1S2/NF undergo LOM during OER. In contrast, Vs-Ni3S2/NF (Fig. S8) shows slight changes, indicating the presence of an AEM pathway. The LOM mechanism has a strong pH dependence on OER reaction due to the non-synergism of proton-electron transfer [45]. Therefore, we evaluated the OER performance of these electrodes under various pH (Figs. S9 and S10). With the increase of pH, the OER performance of Vs-Ni3S2/NF did not change much, while that of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and Ni2Fe1S2/NF was significantly improved. The others are inclined to the LOM mechanism. Fig. 5 d–g display the plots used to calculate the m OH - at 1.56 and 1.58 V for Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF and Vs-Ni3S2/NF, respectively. The slope ( m OH - ) represents the OER reaction order with respect to [OH−] in the RHE scale (Eq. (1)). (1) m O H - = ∂ l o g i ∂ l o g O H - η The mean m OH - for Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF and Vs-Ni3S2/NF are 0.51, 0.68, 0.45 and 0.25, respectively. These values support the involvement of a decoupled electron–proton transfer process occurring prior to or at the turnover limiting step. In the case of proton-coupled electron transfer, the m OH - should be zero on the RHE scale. Such characteristics are indicative of mechanistic pathways involving the lattice oxygen oxidation mechanism [46]. Although Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF and Ni2Fe1S2/NF all have LOM participation, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF exhibits higher m OH - values. This suggests a higher level of participation of LOM. For Vs-Ni3S2/NF, OER mainly follows the AEM, and LOM contributes less. Fig. 5h shows the change of the Ni3+/2+ reduction peak potential with pH, and the slope reflects the acid-base characteristics of the electrochemical reaction, which is usually related to the coupling degree of electron and proton transfer in the reaction. The slope of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF is 126.4 mV pH−1. It was higher than Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF (38.73 mV pH−1), Ni2Fe1S2/NF (54.43 mV pH−1) and Vs-Ni3S2/NF (90.67 mV pH−1). The super-Nernstian shift observed for these peaks with varying pH suggests that more than one proton is released per electron transfer. This phenomenon is typically attributed to the increased acidity of the oxidized state (higher pK a), which promotes the chemical dissociation of hydroxyl groups or water molecules bound to the metal sites. The Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF catalyst displays notably low values, likely resulting from its layered structure, where interlayer cations compete with H+ for participation in the Ni3+/Ni2+ redox process. By obtaining LSV at different temperatures (Fig. S12), the apparent activation energy (E a) of OER can be calculated according to Eq. (2) (2) E a = - R ∂ l n j 0 ∂ 1 T where j 0 denotes the exchange current density. The E a calculation diagram is shown in Fig. 5i. Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF (11.35 kJ mol−1) exhibits a lower E a than Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF (22.46 kJ mol−1), Ni2Fe1S2/NF (27.32 kJ mol−1) and Vs-Ni3S2/NF (40.41 kJ mol−1). These results show that the OER kinetics of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF is the most facile. This indicates that S vacancies and iron doped are beneficial to reduce the OER kinetic barrier. In-situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is an effective method to study the kinetics of electrochemical reactions, especially the adsorption and desorption kinetics of reactants on the electrode surface [47]. Fig. 6 a–d show Bode diagrams of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni3S2/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF at different voltage ranges. The frequency range is 105–10−2 Hz, and the amplitude is 5 mV. The response in the high-frequency region after 1.36 V is related to the oxidation. The response in the low-frequency region is attributed to the heterogeneous charge distribution arising from the oxide phases at the electrode interface [48]. The low-frequency peak is formed during the electrooxidation of the catalyst, which indicates that it is located between the diffusion double layer and the oxide layer generated by the electrooxidation of the catalyst. OER occurs on the oxide layer formed by electrooxidation of the electrocatalyst [49]. For Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni3S2/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, the peaks in the high frequency region drop sharply after 1.36 V, indicating the formation of high-valent nickel species. At the same time, there is an obvious peak in the low frequency region at 1.39 V, which is caused by the formation of electrochemically induced substances on the electrode surface. After 1.39 V, the peak in the low-frequency region shifts significantly toward higher frequencies, accompanied by a gradual decrease in the phase angle. At voltages of 1.39 V or higher, Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni3S2/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF form active hydroxyl oxide substances [28]. Compared with Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni3S2/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF have a lower peak value at low frequencies and a faster decline rate with increasing potential, indicating faster charge transfer kinetics [50,51]. As shown in Fig. S14a–d, Nyquist curves of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and Vs-Ni3S2/NF were collected at different potentials. Obviously, the arc of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF decreases more rapidly with potential than Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF and Vs-Ni3S2/NF, indicating that the electrode has a lower resistance and is more prone to polarization [52]. Fig. 6e illustrates the correlation between the maximum phase angles of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni3S2/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF and the applied potential. The maximum phase angle of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF decreases faster with applied potential than that of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni3S2/NF, and Ni2Fe1S2/NF. Fig. S15 illustrates the relationship between the phase angle and voltage, with the slope indicating the rate of decrease in the maximum phase angle. This suggests that Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF exhibits a lower impedance to the OER process and faster kinetics. For the introduction of Fe3+, the phase angle of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF decreases more rapidly than that of Vs-Ni3S2/NF, indicating that the rate of diffusion-related processes in Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF accelerates as the applied potential increases. This may be related to the electrostatic interaction between the OH− attracting Fe3+ and the surface migration of OH* from the Fe site to the adjacent Ni site that may occur at low potentials [53]. Fig. 6f compares the Bode plot of all electrodes at 1.51 VRHE. For Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, the phase angle is markedly lower than that of the other electrodes, indicating that the adsorption of intermediates occurs more readily. In addition, an equivalent circuit model (Fig. S16) was used to fit the Nyquist diagram corresponding to all electrodes. Fig. 6g compares the Nyquist diagram of all electrodes at 1.51 VRHE. Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF has the smallest R ct, which indicates the easiest charge transport dynamics. The trends in CPE and R ct provide insights into the behavior of surface-bound OH* during the OER process. Fig. 6g illustrates the relationship between CPE and the potential for these electrodes. A higher CPE, indicative of faster OH* accumulation, facilitates more rapid OER kinetics [37]. At 1.16–1.36 VRHE, the CPE increases with the potential as Ni2+/Ni3+ oxidation begins. Vs-Ni3S2/NF shows a slight change at 1.26 VRHE, while Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF, and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF show a significant difference after 1.36 VRHE. Since Vs-Ni3S2/NF has a higher ECSA, there are more active sites for OH* adsorption, so the CPE will also be higher. Subsequently, the CPE of these electrodes decreases due to the formation of oxygen bubbles, which hinder the interaction between the active sites and the electrolyte. That is, the pseudo-capacitance increases as the potential increases, then reaches a constant value and begins to decline [54]. Fig. 6i presents the R total of these electrodes as a function of the applied potential. A smaller R total indicates faster charge transfer kinetics. At the same potential, the R total value of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF is lower than that of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Vs-Ni3S2/NF, and Ni2Fe1S2/NF, indicating that the OH* adsorption kinetics at OER potential is more agile, enhancing charge transfer and intermediate formation [55]. In order to further analyze the formation of intermediates, Laviron analysis was used. Fig. S18a–d shows that the redox constant (K s) of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF (0.032 s−1) is higher than that of Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF (0.023 s−1). Vs-Ni3S2/NF (0.011 s−1) and Ni2Fe1S2/NF (0.017 s−1), which indicate that the coupling strength of the intermediate to the surface metal active site is stronger, the electron transfer on the surface of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF is more agile, and the rate of OH* adsorption and subsequent conversion is higher [56]. The OER reaction kinetics is affected by the adsorption energy of OER intermediates [57]. In the case of MeOH as a probe, OH* can be adsorbed to a large extent by adding MeOH, thus achieving high coverage of OH* [58]. The enhanced current density reflects the unconsumed portion of the adsorbed *OH (Fig. S20). It is noteworthy that the unconsumed portion of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF is significantly lower than Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF, Ni2Fe1S2/NF and Vs-Ni3S2/NF, indicating that more *OHs are adsorbed to participate in the OER process of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF rather than accumulating on the surface. The enhanced effective *OH utilization of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF suggests a substantial improvement in the subsequent intermediate steps, including the rate-determining step (RDS). The results show that the introduction of S vacancies promotes the formation of intermediates and thus promotes OER kinetics. In order to further reveal the effects of S-vacancies and iron-doped on the OER activity of Ni3S2, the DFT calculations of the adsorption free energy (ΔG), charge density difference, electric potential and density of states (DOS) were studied by establishing relevant theoretical models. The introduction of S vacancies and Fe increases the electron density of Ni and shifts the D-band center toward a higher energy level, indicating that doping can regulate the electronic state and the coordination environment of the active site of the catalyst (Fig. 7 a, b). The D-band centers of Ni3S2, Ni2Fe1S2, and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2 are −1.58, −1.43, and −1.16 eV, respectively. This suggests that the introduction of S vacancies and Fe significantly affects the D-band center of Ni. The position of the D-band center of Ni relative to the Fermi level reflects the filling degree of the antibonding state. A relatively high D-band center means that there are more vacancies or antibonding states on the catalyst surface, which helps to reduce the bonding strength with redox intermediates [59]. The calculated charge density difference further reveals the electron transfer behavior (Fig. 7c), where the green and yellow regions indicate electron accumulation and electron depletion regions, respectively. The Fe atom adjacent to the O atom shows significant electron accumulation, suggesting that rapid electron transfer between Ni and Fe can effectively accelerate the formation of OOH* [60]. The local electron density of the Ni atom around the S vacancies of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2 is greater than that of the original Ni3S2 and Ni2Fe1S2, which may be attributed to the contribution of the local electrons accumulated after the removal of the S atom [61]. ΔG graphs of OER were calculated to evaluate their catalytic activity. The results show that when U = 0 V, the RDS of the three models are all the formation process of OOH* generated by O*, where the maximum free energy difference of Ni3S2 is 2.5 eV. The ΔG value of RDS Vs-Ni2Fe1S2 is only 2.01 eV, which is smaller than the 2.45 eV of Ni2Fe1S2 (Fig. 7d). When U = 1.23 V, the RDS of the three models are also the formation process of *OOH intermediates, and the ΔG of RDS corresponding to Ni3S2, Ni2Fe1S2 and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2 are 1.27, 0.42 and 0.23 eV, respectively (Fig. 7e). Through this analysis, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2 shows the best theoretical OER performance and the corresponding OER reaction steps are obtained (Fig. S28). The total state density of Ni3S2, Ni2Fe1S2, and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2 is shown in Fig. 7f. Both Ni2Fe1S2 and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2 exhibit high state density near the Fermi level (E − E f = 0 eV), which indicates that they have good conductivity and are conducive to the electrocatalytic process [46]. In addition, the total DOS of Ni3S2 and Ni2Fe1S2 are weaker than that of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2 near the Fermi level, which reflects that the electron conductivity is improved by introducing S vacancies [62]. As shown in Fig. 7g–i, in Ni3S2, Ni2Fe1S2, and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2, the Fe-3d orbits exhibit a stronger degree of spin splitting than the Ni-3d orbits, which can be seen by the larger difference between the spin-up and spin-down orbits. The results show that the Fe site should be more spin-polarized than the Ni site, that is, the Fe site should have more eg electrons. This weakens the H2O molecule's ability to bond at the Fe site as more eg electrons result in a higher σ* orbital occupancy [63]. As a result, Ni has fewer unfilled 3d eg states than Fe, indicating that Ni interacts more actively with OER intermediates in Ni3S2, Ni2Fe1S2, and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2. For Ni2Fe1S2 and Vs-Ni2Fe1S2, the increase in DOS of S 2p orbitals also suggests that the reactivity can be enhanced by generating sulfur vacancies in Vs-Ni2Fe1S2. In summary, the DFT results further indicate that the introduction of Fe atoms and S vacancies in Ni3S2 can enhance the conductivity of the intermediates by regulating the electronic structure of the intermediates, optimize the adsorption or desorption state of the intermediates, and thus significantly improve the OER activity. Fig. 8 a shows the results of a 100 h galvanostatic test for Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF at a constant current of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH. The overpotential of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF remains stable at 185 mV for 100 h, and temperature changes during the day and night may cause current fluctuations that affect the applied potential. This again shows that Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF has good stability. Fig. 8b shows the LSV curves before and after the Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF stability test. After testing, the overall overpotential changed little, while the Ni3 +/Ni2 + reduction peak showed a slight increase in intensity. This suggests that the catalyst underwent surface restructuring during the OER process, leading to an increase in the number of active Ni sites. Fig. 8c compares the Nyquist plots of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF before and after the long-term constant current test. After OER, R ct increases by approximately 0.5 Ω. This is probably caused by the fact that the surface sulfide is converted into (oxy)hydroxide in the OER process, which prevents the transfer of electrons or the diffusion of the active substance. To directly identify the transition, a constant current test at a low current density was applied (Fig. 8d). The results show that there are four different turning points in Fig. 8d, indicating a three-step transition process of Ni2Fe1S2 → Ni3S2 (Fe leaching) → Ni(OH)2 → NiOOH. The first turning point increases the slope at around 1500 s, indicating the initial Fe leaching step. After another 1000 s, the slope decreases, indicating that Ni(OH)2 is generated in the second step of the surface. A significant increase in slope after about 1 h indicates that the third step changes from Ni(OH)2 to NiOOH. XRD measurements of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF were performed at several intervals throughout the constant current OER process, as shown in Fig. 8e. The diffraction peak intensity of Ni3S2 phase decreases with the prolongation of electrolysis time. During the OER process, which begins in the surface layer, metal sulfides are converted to metal oxides and (oxy)hydroxides. However, no crystallization peaks of any oxygen-containing species appear in Fig. 8e. Fig. 8f compares the Raman spectra before and after the long-term constant current OER test. Stretching vibrations attributed to nickel hydroxide at 458 and 526 cm−1 [38]. This indicates that the sulfides on the surface of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF have been completely converted to amorphous hydroxide and that the amorphous metal oxides and (oxy)hydroxide layers generated on the surface are the true active substances of OER. Fig. S24 shows SEM images of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF after long-term OER. The morphology of the catalyst collapses to a certain extent and almost all the nanosheets are transformed into fine nanoparticles. This suggests that Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF undergoes significant structural restructuring during the electrochemical reaction. This transition may be due to the high voltage or strong oxidizing environment causing the surface layer of the nanosheet to break off, crack or dissolve, and eventually form a more stable but morphologically denser nanoparticle. There are many space between the large number of nanoparticles, which increases the surface area of the catalyst and provides a path for oxygen to be precipitated. Fig. 8g–i show the XPS spectra of the Ni 2p, Fe 2p, and S 2p regions of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF before and after the galvanostatic test. The Ni–S bond disappears, and the deconvolution Ni 2p 3/2 peaks at 855.5 and 856.8 eV indicate the presence of Ni2+ and Ni3+ species, respectively. The Fe 2p 3/2 peak can be deconvolved to Fe3+ (712.1 eV) and the satellite peak (719.2 eV). In the OER process, the presence of Fe allows the Ni site on the surface of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF to easily bind to OH to form active Ni-*OOH intermediates [64]. Interestingly, the binding energy of Fe did not change significantly before and after OER process. Therefore, the main active site is Ni and that there is a synergy between Ni and Fe in this system, thus enhancing the performance for Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF catalytic OER. The introduction of Fe not only acts as an accelerator for surface construction, but also as a corrosion inhibitor to stabilize part of the MS bond in the OER process, achieving a balance between activity and durability [65]. In Fig. 8i, the peak of S2− after OER almost disappears, indicating complete conversion of the surface sulfide to oxides and (oxy)hydroxides. In addition, the XPS peak of SO4 2− was observed, which results from the oxidation of sulfides adsorbed on the surface of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF. The interaction of SO4 2− and the Ni site facilitated electrochemical reconstruction of the pre-catalyst [39]. In summary, the real electrochemical active substances of OER are surface (oxy)hydroxides. To explore the overall water-splitting performance, we first tested the HER performance of different catalysts in 1 M KOH. Fig. 9 a shows the polarization curve of these electrodes in 1 M KOH. Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF has the best alkaline HER properties compared to other catalysts. At the same time, as shown in Fig. 9c, a low overpotential of only 133 mV can bring the cathode current density of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF to −10 mA cm−2, which is significantly lower than Ni2Fe1S2/NF (160 mV), Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF (293 mV) and Vs-Ni3S2/NF (169 mV). In order to study the HER kinetic behavior of various catalysts, the Tafel slope diagram (Fig. 9b) is obtained. The Tafel slope value of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF (89.46 mV dec−1) is lower than that of Ni2Fe1S2/NF (94.25 mV dec−1), Vs-Ni3S2/NF (98.94 mV dec−1) and Ni2Fe1-LDH/NF (109.13 mV dec−1), indicating that Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF has good HER kinetics. Subsequently, a lab-scale electrolyzer composed of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF as both anode and cathode was assembled to explore their potential applications in OWS. As shown in Fig. 9d, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF can achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a low cell voltage of 1.56 V. Chronoamperometry tests of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF (Fig. 9e) shows excellent long-term durability, with a current density retention rate of nearly 100% after 100 h of continuous electrolysis. To test the practical application of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF electrodes in commercial alkaline water splitting applications, an electrolyzer consisting of a pair of Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF electrodes was tested in a 30 wt% KOH electrolyte. Fig. 9f shows the LSV of the cathode, indicating that Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF has excellent industrial water-splitting performance. Specifically, the cells achieve current densities of 10, 50, 100, and 250 mA cm−2 at cell voltages of 1.42, 1.47, 1.5, and 1.55 V, respectively. In addition, the Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF electrodes maintain good stability at 100 mA cm−2 current density for 100 h (Fig. 9g). Finally, the cell performance is compared with the recently reported of different catalysts in 1 M KOH and 30 wt% KOH (Fig. 9h and Tables S4 and S5). These results indicate that Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF is a promising candidate for an efficient and sustainable anode material for industrial alkaline water splitting applications. 4 Conclusions In summary, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF was successfully prepared on the surface of NF by hydrothermal and solvothermal methods. Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF exhibits excellent electrocatalytic performance and long-term durability under the synergistic regulation of S-vacancies and iron-doped. At current densities of 10 mA cm−2 and 500 mA cm−2, the overpotential is 185 (±5) mV and 248 (±5) mV, respectively, and the long-term stability is maintained at 500 mA cm−2 for 350 h. The unique morphology and pitting formation of the nanosheet, as well as the appropriate electronic structure through vacancy adjustment, are the reasons for the excellent performance. Lower E a, R ct and Tafel slope values and higher Ks on Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF indicate that charge redistribution due to Fe and S vacancies changes the adsorption energy of hydroxyl at the Ni site during OER. The change in the OER mechanism is due to the increased acidity of the Ni site caused by adjacent Fe, which facilitates the decoupled proton and electron transfer processes. The DFT results show that the introduction of Fe atoms and S vacancies in Ni3S2 can regulate the electronic structure of the intermediate to enhance the conductivity of the intermediate, optimize the adsorption or desorption state of the intermediate, and thus improve the OER activity. In addition, under the industrial condition of 30% KOH at 70 °C, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF catalysts also exhibit low overpotential (270 mV at 100 mA cm−2) and high alkaline resistance (100 h at 100 mA cm−2). This work provides new insights into the synthesis of electrocatalysts with higher OER properties and further aids the development of industrial-scale electrochemical hydrogen production. coredata.dc:description: The development of high-performance and stable electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is essential to improve the overall efficiency of water splitting. Here, S-vacancies and iron-doped nickel sulfide nanosheets (Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF) were successfully prepared on the surface of nickel foam via solvothermal reaction of nickel–iron layered double hydroxide with sublimed sulfur added with sodium borohydride. Under the synergistic regulation of iron-doped and S-vacancies, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF shows excellent electrocatalytic performance and long-term durability. To reach current densities of 10 and 500 mA cm−2, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF requires only 185 (±5) and 248 (±5) mV overpotential, respectively, and can maintain long stability for 350 h at 500 mA cm−2. The change of the mechanical pathway from adsorbate evolution mechanism to lattice oxygen oxidation mechanism is due to the increased acidity of the Ni site in Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF, which facilitates the decouped proton and electron transfer process. Density functional calculation results show that the introduction of Fe atoms and S vacancies in Ni3S2 can enhance the conductivity of the intermediates by regulating the electronic structure of the intermediates, optimize the adsorption or desorption energy, and thus significantly improve the OER activity. For Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF (+, −) cell, a voltage of 1.56 V is required to achieve 10 mA cm−2. In addition, Vs-Ni2Fe1S2/NF catalyst also showed low overpotential (270 mV at 100 mA cm−2) and high alkaline tolerance (100 h at 100 mA cm−2) at 30 wt% KOH of 70 °C. This shows that it has potential industrial application.
